Title.evidence: Randomised Controlled Trial of Hyperinsulinemic Normoglycemia in Cardiac Surgery

Trial_Design.evidence: Eligible cardiac surgical patients were randomized

Participants.evidence: Eligible cardiac surgical patients were randomized to intraoperative glycemic management

Intervention.evidence: randomized to intraoperative glycemic management with either hyperinsulinemic normoglycemia or standard glycemic management

Objective.evidence: Hyperinsulinemic normoglycemia is hypothesized to enhance myocardial glucose uptake and utilization

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was a composite of 30-day mortality, mechanical circulatory support, infection, renal or neurologic morbidity

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomization was computer-generated with allocation concealment

Number_Randomised.evidence: A total of 1,439 patients were randomized (709 to hyperinsulinemic normoglycemia, 730 to standard management)

Number_Analysed.evidence: The analysis followed an intention-to-treat approach

Result_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome occurred in 49 (6.9%) patients in the hyperinsulinemic group compared to 82 (11.2%) in the standard group (P<0.0085); relative risk 0.62 (95% CI 0.39, 0.97), P=0.0043

Harms.evidence: Severe hypoglycemia (<40 mg·dL−1) was observed in 6 (0.9%) patients
